headline: Sticks and Stones
description: A parable exploring the power of words — how they wound, heal, and shape the soul. From womb to childhood taunts, to brokenness and restoration, the tale traces a man’s journey from curse to blessing, reminding that words are not noise but builders of worlds.
author: Aleksandr Agnitio
whyItMatters: This story underscores the weight of words. It reframes the childhood rhyme 'sticks and stones may break my bones' into a deeper truth: that words wound as much as they heal, carrying the power to define a life. By healing, by reclaiming blessing, the protagonist shows that mastery of one’s words restores not just speech but light itself.

motifMap.meaning: Childhood rhyme turned into a parable of wounding words and resilience
The inner gift and voice that can be rekindled after loss
Moment of pain and clarity; catalyst for healing

articleExcerpt: "Now a man, he saw what words truly were: not noise in the air, but the builders of worlds."
sourceFragments: One day the boy came home crying. A classmate had called him stupid and slow. His parents gave him the rhyme they themselves had been taught: 'Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me.'
The light once spoken into him was forgotten. The care his parents had for each other, devoured.
Now a man, he saw what words truly were: not noise in the air, but the builders of worlds.

associatedMedia.description: Classical-style painting of figures: a man exhaling light, a woman cradling glowing words, and others burdened by stones labeled with curses.
